div.l: And fonde þe bedde and thoȝht noȝht but goode
By cause þat þe Cradell by it stode
And nyste wher͗e sche was for it was derke
But fair͗e and wele sche crepe in to þe clerke
And lieth full still ande wolde haf cauȝt a slepe
With in a while þis Iohn þe clerke up lepe
And on þis goode wiffe he leith on soore
So mery a fitte ne had sche not full ȝor͗e
He prikketh harde and depe as he wer͗e madde
This lyff iolily hauen þis two clerkes hadde
Til þat þe thridde cok began̄ to synge
¶ Aleyn wex wery in þe dawenynge
For he hadde swonken all þat longe nyȝht
And seide far͗e wele malyn̄ swete wyȝhte
The day is comen̄ I may no leng̉er bide
But euer mor͗e wher so I go or ride
I am þine own̄ clerke so haf I hele
Nowe der͗e leman qduod sche go far͗e wele
But or þou go / oo thyng I woll þe tell
Whan̄ þat þou wendest homward by þe mylle
Riȝht at þe entr͗e of þe dor͗e behynde
Thou schalt a kake of half a busshell fynde
That was y maked of þine owne mele
Whiche þat I helpe my sir͗e for to stele
And gode lēmman god þe saue and kepe
And with þat worde al moste he gan to wepe
Aleyn up a riste and thouȝht or þat it dawe
I woll go crepen̄ in be my felowe
And fonde þe credill with his honde onon̄
By god thought he al wronge I haf mysgoon̄
Myn hede is toty of my swynke to nyȝht
That makith me þat I go not a right
I wote wele by þe cradell I haf mysgoo
Her͗e lieth þe meller͗e and his wiff also
And forthe he goith on xx · deuell wey
Vn to þe bedde þer as þe myller leye
He wende haf cropen̄ be his felowe Iohn
And by þe miller in he crepe onoon̄
And kauȝhte hym by þe nekke and softe he spake
He seide þou Iohn þou swynes heued a wake
For cristes soule and her͗e a noble game
For by þat lorde þat called is seynt Iame
As I haf thries in þis schorte nyȝht
Swyved þe millers doght̉er bolte up riȝht
Whil þou haste as a coward bene a gaste
Ȝa fals harlot qduod þe myller haste
